title: 115_s1774
content: The Employee Rights Act, also known as the National Labor Relations Act, includes amendments to protect the rights of employees. The Employee Rights Act, or the National Labor Relations Act, is amended to address unfair labor practices and election procedures for collective bargaining representatives. The Employee Rights Act requires secret paper ballot elections for bargaining units with significant turnover, expansion, or merger, either before the expiration of a collective bargaining agreement or every three years if no agreement is in place. The Employee Rights Act mandates secret paper ballot elections for bargaining units experiencing turnover, expansion, or merger exceeding 50 percent of the existing unit. If a majority rejects representation by the labor organization, certification is withdrawn, representation ceases, and contractual obligations end. Amendments to Section 9 of the National Labor Relations Act ensure fair representation in elections. The Employee Rights Act mandates secret paper ballot elections for bargaining units with significant turnover, expansion, or merger. Amendments to Section 9 of the National Labor Relations Act ensure fair representation in elections by specifying procedures for notification, review, and exclusion of eligible voters. The Employee Rights Act mandates secret paper ballot elections for bargaining units with significant turnover, expansion, or merger. Amendments to Section 9 of the National Labor Relations Act ensure fair representation in elections by specifying procedures for notification, review, exclusion of eligible voters, and conducting hearings before a qualified officer to resolve jurisdictional and eligibility issues. The Employee Rights Act mandates secret paper ballot elections for bargaining units with significant turnover, expansion, or merger. Amendments to Section 10 of the National Labor Relations Act introduce penalties for labor organizations that interfere with employees' rights to form or join a labor organization or refrain from doing so, including the filing of decertification petitions. Penalties include liability for lost wages, unlawfully collected dues or fees, and liquidated damages. Labor organizations interfering with decertification petitions are prohibited from filing objections to related elections. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to ensure employees' rights to vote by secret ballot on collective bargaining agreements and strikes. Employees in a bargaining unit represented by a labor organization have the same voting rights as members. Additionally, employees have the right not to subsidize nonrepresentational activities of labor organizations. SEC. 106. RIGHT NOT TO SUBSIDIZE LABOR ORGANIZATION NONREPRESENTATIONAL ACTIVITIES. The text chunk discusses limitations on the use of labor organization dues and the requirement for employee authorization for non-representational activities. Additionally, it outlines the conditions for commencing a strike with the consent of a majority of represented unit employees through a secret ballot vote. The text chunk discusses the process for secret ballot votes on collective bargaining agreements and the reporting requirements for labor organizations under the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to make it unlawful to use force or violence to obtain rights or compensation related to employment. Violators may face fines or imprisonment. This does not exempt conduct from being defined as extortion. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to prohibit labor organizations or their agents from engaging in conduct that constitutes extortion as defined in section 1951(b)(2) of title 18, United States Code.
